Abstract: Estimation of worker reliability on microtask crowdsourcing platforms has gained attention from many researchers. Existence of spammers is harmful as they increase the cost of microtasking and will negatively affect the answer aggregation process. Hence, to discriminate spammers and non-spammers one needs to measure worker reliability to predict how likely that a worker put an effort in solving a task. In this paper we introduce a new reliability estimation algorithm works based on bee colony algorithm called REBECO. This algorithm relies on Gaussian process model to estimate reliability of workers dynamically. With bees that go in search of pollen, some are more successful than the others. This maps well to our problem, where some workers (i.e., bees) are more successful than other workers for a given task thus, giving rise to a reliability measure. Answer aggregation with respect to worker reliability rates has been considered as a suitable replacement for conventional majority voting. We compared REBECO with majority voting using two real world datasets. The results indicate that REBECO is able to outperform MV significantly.
Author Keywords: Bee colony;Crowdsourcing;Gaussian process model;Worker reliability estimation

Abstract: In relational database systems declarative crowdsourcing enables the user to avoid the complexities while obtaining desired results from relation database. Our proposed system provides the user the facility to submit queries in the form of comments. In this way the user can ask for some specific information in a more expressive way and the results obtained will be more accurate and related according to the user's desire. In our presented system the user will place queries in the form of triplets. CoEx Deco is a system that will answer the user queries over a Simple Protocol and RDF Query Language (SPARQL) Query on Resource Description Framework (RDF) together obtaining data from crowd in form of triplet. We have made the user free to comment anything about a specific noun in form of triplet and our system will make a seamless integration of user entered data along with data collected from the crowd. In our presented system the user can enter the query in form of triplet and each triplet consists of a subject and an object, both labeled with a predicate. In other words we can say that the user can enter a query in the form of comments about a specific noun and each comment should contain these three things which are mentioned above. The query will be then executed and the user will get the desired results from the RDF database. RDF database is in the form of directed labeled graphs in which each edge represents a triplet. The graph matching technique is constructed by the patterns of triples. When a query is evaluated the input graph of RDF is matched against the inside variables of triple patterns. In this way the user can place more expressive queries which will be helpful in obtaining more accurate desired results.
IEEE Terms: Resource description framework;Crowdsourcing;Probabilistic logic;Database languages;Semantics;Relational databases
